titleStmt.title: Hor. Lib. 1 Ep. 7
To the Right Honbl 08 08__ the Earl

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: by the Same
Strenuus et Fortis causisque Philippus agendis &c.
Harley the Nations great support
Returning home one day from Court,
His mind with publick cares possess'd
All Europes business in his breast
Observ'd a Parson near Whithall
Cheapning Old Authors on a Stall
The Preist was pretty well in Case
And shew'd some Humour in his Face
Look'd with an Easie careless Mien
A Perfect Stranger to the Spleen
Of Size that might a Pulpit fill
But more inclining to sit still
My Lord who if a Man may Say it
Loves mischeif better then his Meat
Was now disposed to crack a Jest
And bid friend Lewis go in quest
(This Lewis is a cunning Shaver
And very much in Harley's Favour)
Inquire, who might this Parson be,
What was his Name in what Degree
If possible to learn his Story
And whether he was Whig or Tory.
Lewis his Patrons humour knows
Away upon his Errand goes,
And quickly did the matter sift
Found out that this was Doctor Swift
A Clergyman of Special Note
For shuning those of his own Coate
Which made his Brethern of the Gown
Take care betimes to run him Down
No Libertine nor over nice
Addicted to no sort of Vice
Went where he pleas'd said what he thought
Not rich, but ow'd no man a groat
In State opinions a la mode
He hated Wharton like a Toad
Had given the over erasure Faction many a wound
And Libell'd all the Juncto round
Kept Company with Men of Wit
Who often father'd what he Writ
His works were hawk'd in ev'ry Street
But seldom rose above a Sheet
Of late indeed the paper stamp
Did very much his Genius cramp
And since he cou'd not spend his Fire
He now intended to retire
Said Harley I desire to know
From his own mouth if this be so
Step to the Doctor strait and say
I'd have him dine with me to day
Swift seem'd to wonder what he meant
Nor would beleive my Lord had sent
So never offer'd once to Stir
But coldly said Your Servant Sir
Does he refuse me Harley cry'd
He does with Insolence and Pride
Some few day's after Harley spies
The Doctor fastned by the Eyes
At Charing Crose among the Rout
Where painted Monsters are hung out
He pull'd the string and stop'd his Coach
Beckning the Doctor to approach
Swift who could neither fly nor hide
Came Sneaking by the Chariot Side
And offer'd many a lame excuse
He never meant the least abuce
My Lord────The Honr
you design'd
Extremly proud──but I had dine'd
I·am Sure I never shou'd neglect
No Man alive has more respect
Well I Shall think of that aboveline no more
If you'l be sure to aboveline come at Four
The Doctor now obeys the Summons
Likes both his Company and Commons
Displays his Talent sits till ten
Next day Invited comes again
Soon grows Domestick seldom failes
Either at Morning or at Meals
Come early and departed late
In short the Gudgeon took the Bait
My Lord would carry on the Jest
And down to Windsor takes his GuestSwift much admires the Place and Air
And longs to be a Cannon there
In Summer round the Park to ride
In Winter never to reside
A Cannon that's a place too mean,
No Doctor you Shall be a Dean
Two Dozen Cannons round your Stall
And you the Tyrant o're them all
You·correctingyou need but cross the Irish Seas
To live in plenty Pow'r and Ease
Poor Swift departs and what is worse
With borrow'd money in his purse
Travel at least an hundred Leagues
And Suffers numberless fatigues
Suppose him now a Dean compleat
Devoutly lolling on his Seat
The Silver Verge with decent pride
Stuch underneath his Cusheon side
Suppose him gone through all Vexations
Patents Installmts
Abjurations
First fruits and Tenths and Chapter Treats
Dues Payments fees Demands and Cheats
The Wicked Laity's contriveing
To hinder Clergymen from thriveing
Now all the Doctors money Spent
His Tents
wrong him in his rent
The Farmers spightfully combin'd
Force him to take his Tyths in kind
And 1The Dean's Agent a French man Davisol discounts arreares
By Bills for Taxes and repaires
Poor Swift with all his losses vext
Not knowing where to turn him next
Above a Thousand pound in Debt
Takes Horse and in a mighty frett
Rides day and night at such a rate
He Soon arrives at Harley's Gate
But was so dirty pale and thin
Old Read wou'd hardly let him in
Said Harley welcome Reverend Dean
What makes your Worship look so lean
Why sure you won't appear in Town
With that old Wig and rusty Gown
I doubt Your Heart is set on pelf
So much that you neglect Your Self
What I Suppose now Stocks are high
You've some good Purchase in your Eye
Or is your money out at use
Truce Good My Lord I beg a Truce
The Doctor in a Passion cry'd
Your Raillery is misaplied
I have Experience dearly bought
You know I am not worth a Groat
But you resolv'd to have your Jest
And 'twas a folly to contest
Then since you now have done your worst
Pray leave me where you found me first170-020B
